metadata.titleEn: Water and heat fluxes over the Tibetan Plateau from 2001 to 2010
metadata.description: This data set contains 2001-2018 monthly mean surface energy flux of the qinghai-tibet plateau, and the actual amount of evaporation, the spatial resolution of 0.1 degrees.Data set mainly by satellite remote sensing data (MODIS) and reanalysis meteorological data (CMFD) as input, use of the surface energy balance system (SEBS) to calculate the model.In the process of calculating turbulent flux parameterization scheme is introduced time grid terrain drag, improve the simulation of the surface sensible heat and latent heat fluxes.In addition, the use of the Tibetan plateau six turbulent flux station observation data of the model output quantity of evaporation is verified, showed high precision.The data set can be used to study the qinghai-tibet plateau land interaction between gas and water circulation characteristics.
metadata.instructions: Data storage format for the standard NetCDF format, including time and latitude and longitude information, can use NCL directly read, Python and Matlab software.

background: As the birthplace of Asia’s major rivers, the Tibetan Plateau (TP), famous as the “Water Tower of Asia”, is essential to the Asian energy and water cycles (Immerzeel et al., 2010; Yao et al., 2012). Consuming around two-thirds of global terrestrial precipitation, evapotranspiration (ET) is a crucial component that affects the exchange of water and energy between the land surface and the atmosphere (Oki and Kanae, 2006; Fisher et al., 2017). ET is also a key factor modulating regional and global weather and climate. Total evaporation from large lakes of the TP has been quantitatively estimated recently (B. Wang et al., 2020); however, the terrestrial ET on the TP and its spatial and temporal changes remain very uncertain. Although Epan and potential ET suggest the long-term variability in ET according to the complementary relationship (CR) between Epan and actual ET (ET a) (Zhang et al., 2007), these measures cannot precisely depict the spatial pattern of trends in ET a. Employing only routine meteorological observations without requiring any vegetation and soil information is the most significant advantage of CR models (Szilagyi et al., 2017). However, numerous assumptions and requirements of validations of key parameters limit the application and performance of CR models over different climate conditions. Satellite remote sensing (RS) provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics that affect ET, for example, land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index.
research objective: Thus, in this study, with full consideration of the recent developments in the SEBS model over the TP, we aim to (1) develop an 18-year (2001–2018) ET a product of the TP, along with independent validations against EC observations; (2) quantify the spatiotemporal variability in the ET a in the TP; and (3) uncover the main factors dominating the changes in ETa, using the estimated product.
challenges: However, spatial distribution and temporal changes in ET a over the Tibetan Plateau (TP) remain very uncertain. However, the fetch of the EC observation is on the order of hundreds of meters, thus impeding the ability to capture the plateau-scale variations in ET a. However, numerous assumptions and requirements of validations of key parameters limit the application and performance of CR models over different climate conditions. The SEBS-estimated ETa is at a resolution of around 10 km, while the footprint of EC-observed ETa values ranges from a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters. Note that the energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation is neglected. Thus, the dataset is likely to be less reliable over the glacier and permafrost and in the winter season.
methods: The SEBS model (Su, 2002) was used to derive land surface energy flux components in the present study. The SEBS-estimated ETa was validated against EC observations at six flux stations on the TP at a monthly scale. In situ observations, satellite-based products, and meteorological forcing data were used in this study to estimate monthly ETa over the TP area. The 3-hourly CMFD data were averaged into daily and then into monthly data to be consistent with MODIS products in terms of temporal resolution.
dataset: The CMFD, which was developed based on the released China Meteorological Administration (CMA) data (He et al., 2020), was used as model input. MODIS monthly land surface products, including land surface temperature and emissivity, land surface albedo, and vegetation index, provide land surface conditions for the SEBS model. In situ EC data observed at six flux stations on the TP were used to validate model results. The dataset presented and analyzed in this article has been released and is available for free download from the Science Data Bank (https://doi.org/10.11922/sciencedb.t00000.00010, Han et al., 2020b) and from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (https://doi.org/10.11888/Hydro.tpdc.270995, Han et al., 2020a).
findings: The domain mean of annual ETa on the TP decreased slightly (−1.45 mm yr−1, p< 0.05) from 2001 to 2018. The annual ETa increased significantly at a rate of 2.62 mm yr−1 (p< 0.05) in the eastern sector of the TP (long >90◦E) but decreased significantly at a rate of −5.52 mm yr−1 (p< 0.05) in the western sector of the TP (long <90◦E). The mean annual ET a during 2001–2018 and over the whole TP was 496 ±23 mm. Thus, the total evapotranspiration from the terrestrial surface of the TP was 1238.3±57.6 km3 yr−1.

Verification.Question: Does the SEBS model use satellite remote sensing data to estimate terrestrial evapotranspiration in the Tibetan Plateau?

Disjunctive.Question: Which validation method is more commonly used for evapotranspiration models in the Tibetan Plateau: comparison with eddy covariance flux station data, ground-based meteorological observations, or other validation techniques?
Disjunctive.Answer: comparison with eddy covariance flux station data

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used to estimate evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: In situ observations, satellite-based products, meteorological forcing data

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are associated with the spatial distribution and temporal changes of actual evapotranspiration data on the Tibetan Plateau?
Where can datasets related to the evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau be accessed?
Concept Completion.Answer: Science Data Bank and National Tibetan Plateau Data Center

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using remote sensing data for estimating land surface energy fluxes in diverse climatic conditions?
Example.Answer: One challenge is that numerous assumptions and requirements of validations of key parameters limit the application and performance of complementary relationship (CR) models over different climate conditions, particularly when trying to depict spatial patterns of trends in ETa.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that could be used to validate model results of land surface processes in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: In situ EC data observed at six flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau were used to validate the model results of ETa derived from the SEBS model.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the energy flux components used in the data collection methods for the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: surface energy balance, MODIS satellite data, land surface temperature, albedo, vegetation index, CMFD meteorological data, turbulent fluxes, sensible heat fluxes, latent heat fluxes

Feature Specification.Question: What features of satellite remote sensing data make it suitable for estimating evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: temporally frequent measurements, spatially contiguous measurements, land surface temperature, albedo, vegetation index

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are associated with validating model outputs against in-situ observations on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: mismatch between spatial resolution of model estimates (around 10 km) and footprint of in-situ EC observations (a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters), neglect of energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes and sublimation

Quantification.Question: How many flux stations were used to validate the model outputs for evapotranspiration calculations on the Tibetan Plateau?
Over how many years was the data collected to analyze the spatiotemporal variability of evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What does 'satellite remote sensing' mean in the context of data collection for land surface characteristics?
Definition.Answer: Satellite remote sensing provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics that affect evapotranspiration, such as land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'subgrid terrain drag parameterization scheme' in the context of modeling surface energy fluxes?
Definition.Answer: A subgrid terrain drag parameterization scheme is a method introduced in the process of calculating turbulent fluxes to improve the simulation of surface sensible heat flux and latent heat flux, enhancing the accuracy of surface energy flux modeling.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'CMFD data' in the modeling of land surface energy balance?
Definition.Answer: CMFD data, developed based on the China Meteorological Administration data, is used as model input to provide meteorological forcing data that helps estimate monthly actual evapotranspiration over the Tibetan Plateau area.

Comparison.Question: How do satellite remote sensing (RS) and eddy covariance (EC) observations compare in their effectiveness for estimating evapotranspiration (ET) over the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Satellite remote sensing provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements, allowing for broader coverage over the Tibetan Plateau, whereas eddy covariance observations offer high accuracy but are limited to specific flux stations, capturing only localized variations.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods between using the SEBS model and the complementary relationship (CR) models for estimating actual evapotranspiration (ETa) on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The SEBS model uses satellite-based products and meteorological forcing data to derive land surface energy flux components, while CR models rely solely on routine meteorological observations without requiring vegetation and soil information, though they involve numerous assumptions and parameter validations.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of validating key parameters in complementary relationship (CR) models compare to those encountered in the SEBS model when estimating ETa over the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: CR models face challenges due to numerous assumptions and the need for parameter validation across different climate conditions, whereas the SEBS model primarily contends with resolution differences between estimated and observed data, as well as unaccounted energy processes like freeze-thaw and sublimation.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential limitations of using reanalysis meteorological data and satellite products in estimating evapotranspiration over diverse climatic conditions like those found in the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Reanalysis meteorological data, while comprehensive, may not capture local-scale variations due to their coarse spatial resolution. Satellite products depend on clear-sky conditions and can miss data due to cloud cover. Additionally, the assumptions required in modeling processes, such as those in the complementary relationship models, may not hold across the varied climatic zones of the Tibetan Plateau, leading to uncertainties in evapotranspiration estimates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes uncertainties in the spatial distribution and temporal changes of actual evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in the spatial distribution and temporal changes of actual evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau arise from the limitations of the complementary relationship models, which rely on numerous assumptions and require validations of key parameters across different climate conditions. Additionally, the fetch of eddy covariance (EC) observations is limited to the order of hundreds of meters, impeding the ability to capture plateau-scale variations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might the energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation affect the reliability of datasets over glacier and permafrost regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The neglect of energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation could affect the reliability of datasets over glacier and permafrost regions because these processes are significant in such environments. As a result, datasets are likely to be less reliable in these areas, particularly during the winter season when such processes are more prevalent.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in estimating actual evapotranspiration using satellite-based remote sensing over large areas like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in estimating actual evapotranspiration using satellite-based remote sensing over large areas like the Tibetan Plateau include the differences in spatial resolution between the SEBS-estimated evapotranspiration, which is around 10 km, and the footprint of EC-observed evapotranspiration values, which ranges from a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters. Additionally, the lack of energy consumption consideration for freeze–thaw processes and sublimation further complicates accurate estimation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the introduction of sub-grid terrain drag parameterization in the calculation of turbulent fluxes affect the simulation of surface sensible and latent heat fluxes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Introducing sub-grid terrain drag parameterization in calculating turbulent fluxes improves the simulation of surface sensible and latent heat fluxes, enhancing the model's ability to accurately capture surface energy dynamics on complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential limitations of using reanalysis meteorological data as input for the surface energy balance system model in varying climate conditions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using reanalysis meteorological data can limit the application and performance of the surface energy balance system model under different climate conditions due to numerous assumptions and the need for validation of key parameters, which may not fully capture local climate variations and processes such as freeze-thaw and sublimation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of utilizing satellite remote sensing data in developing datasets for evapotranspiration estimation in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Satellite remote sensing provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics that affect evapotranspiration, such as land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index. These measurements help in overcoming the limitations of traditional models that rely on routine meteorological observations and often fail to capture the spatial pattern of trends in actual evapotranspiration.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate evapotranspiration datasets against eddy covariance observations in research on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Validation against eddy covariance observations is crucial because it ensures the accuracy of the SEBS-estimated actual evapotranspiration. By comparing model outputs with actual observations at six flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau, researchers can verify the reliability and precision of the datasets, which are essential for understanding the spatiotemporal variability and main factors affecting evapotranspiration in the area.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of addressing spatial distribution and temporal changes in evapotranspiration when creating a dataset for the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing spatial distribution and temporal changes in evapotranspiration is significant because these factors remain very uncertain over the Tibetan Plateau. A comprehensive understanding of these elements is essential for accurately capturing the plateau-scale variations in evapotranspiration, which is affected by various climatic conditions and processes such as freeze-thaw cycles and sublimation, especially in glacier and permafrost regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in using the SEBS model to estimate land surface energy flux components and actual evapotranspiration over the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The SEBS model is employed to derive land surface energy flux components. The model uses satellite-based products such as MODIS for land surface conditions, including land surface temperature and albedo, and the CMFD meteorological data as inputs. The SEBS-estimated actual evapotranspiration (ETa) is validated against in situ EC observations at six flux stations on a monthly scale. The CMFD data, initially 3-hourly, are averaged into daily and then into monthly data to match the temporal resolution of MODIS products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the challenges in validating the SEBS model outputs with EC observations, and how are these challenges addressed in the context of the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One challenge in validating SEBS model outputs with EC observations is the scale mismatch, as SEBS estimates ETa at a resolution of about 10 km, while EC observations have a footprint ranging from a few dozen to a few hundred meters. Additionally, energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes and sublimation is neglected, making the dataset less reliable over glaciers, permafrost, and during winter. These challenges are addressed by validating SEBS outputs with EC data from six flux stations on a monthly scale and using advanced parameterization techniques like subgrid terrain drag to improve simulation accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods allow for the accurate estimation of evapotranspiration over diverse terrains like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Satellite remote sensing, particularly using MODIS products, combined with meteorological reanalysis data such as CMFD, enable the estimation of evapotranspiration by providing measurements of land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index. These are further validated against in situ data from flux stations.

Enablement.Question: How do current technological advancements facilitate the validation of evapotranspiration data collected via remote sensing on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the SEBS model allows for the integration of satellite and in situ data, enabling validation of evapotranspiration estimates at a monthly scale. The model outputs are validated against EC observations from flux stations on the plateau, ensuring accuracy in the data.

Enablement.Question: Which conditions or methodologies are critical for improving the reliability of evapotranspiration datasets over regions with complex climate conditions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Incorporating subgrid topographic drag parameterization can improve the simulation of surface sensible and latent heat fluxes. Additionally, addressing the limitations of CR models and accounting for energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes can enhance dataset reliability over challenging conditions such as glaciers and permafrost.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using satellite remote sensing over traditional meteorological observations for estimating evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Satellite remote sensing provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics such as land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index, which can affect evapotranspiration. This approach avoids the numerous assumptions and validation requirements of key parameters that limit the application and performance of Complementary Relationship models over different climate conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the SEBS model face challenges in accurately representing evapotranspiration in areas with glacier and permafrost or during winter seasons on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation is neglected in the SEBS model. This omission likely makes the dataset less reliable over glacier and permafrost areas and in the winter season, thus posing a challenge for accurate representation in such conditions.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you foresee in validating model outputs of land surface energy flux components using ground-based observations in the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: One of the main challenges is the scale mismatch between model outputs and the fetch of the eddy covariance (EC) observations, which are on the order of hundreds of meters. This impedes capturing plateau-scale variations in evapotranspiration. Additionally, the energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation is neglected, which may reduce reliability over glaciers and permafrost and during the winter season.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using the SEBS model for estimating actual evapotranspiration in diverse climate conditions across the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The SEBS model, while useful, involves numerous assumptions and requires validation of key parameters, which can limit its application and performance under various climate conditions. The model's resolution may also not align with the finer footprint of EC observations, leading to potential discrepancies in estimates.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how satellite remote sensing can be effectively used to estimate evapotranspiration over such a vast and diverse region like the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite remote sensing provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics that affect evapotranspiration, such as land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how to accurately validate model outputs for evapotranspiration when the spatial resolution of the estimated data and in situ observations differ significantly.
Assertion.Answer: The SEBS-estimated evapotranspiration was validated against EC observations at six flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau at a monthly scale, despite the resolution differences, by using a combination of in situ observations, satellite-based products, and meteorological forcing data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how different assumptions and parameter validations affect the use of complementary relationship models for estimating terrestrial evapotranspiration.
Assertion.Answer: Complementary relationship models employ routine meteorological observations without requiring vegetation and soil information, which is a significant advantage, but numerous assumptions and validations of key parameters limit their application and performance across different climate conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please elaborate on the data collection methods used for estimating evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau, including the integration of different data sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: The estimation of evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau involved the use of the SEBS model, which integrates satellite-based products and meteorological forcing data. In situ EC data from six flux stations were utilized for validation, while MODIS products provided land surface conditions such as temperature, emissivity, albedo, and vegetation index. CMFD data, averaged from 3-hourly to monthly, were used as model input.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential sources or strategies for expanding and enhancing datasets related to surface energy flux and evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies could involve leveraging more comprehensive satellite remote sensing data to increase spatial and temporal coverage, incorporating additional in situ observations from a wider network of flux stations, and improving model parameterizations to better account for regional climate conditions, especially in challenging environments like glaciers and permafrost.
